complexityChecks.description: When supported by the stack, run cyclomatic complexity or similar metrics in CI as a warning-only check initially.

qualityGatePolicy.description: New quality checks should warn on existing code and fail CI only for violations introduced in new or changed code, to reduce friction on legacy codebases.

migrationGuide.title: Establish Local Safety Nets First
migrationGuide.description: Start by adding pre-commit hooks and core formatting/linting so developers get fast feedback without touching CI.
migrationGuide.notes: Keep hooks fast and focused on changed files to avoid slowing down day-to-day work.

migrationGuide.title: Mirror Local Checks in CI (Soft-Fail on Legacy)
migrationGuide.description: Introduce CI quality gates that mirror local checks, but treat existing violations as warnings wherever possible.
migrationGuide.notes: Use diff-based tools or baselines so only new violations break builds; legacy issues remain visible but non-blocking.

migrationGuide.title: Add Type Safety, Coverage, and Dependency Security
migrationGuide.description: Enable type-checking, coverage thresholds, and dependency/vulnerability scanning with gradual enforcement.
migrationGuide.notes: Pin tool and runtime versions in CI and containers to avoid flaky differences across environments.

migrationGuide.title: Layer in Docs, Governance, and Recommended Checks
migrationGuide.description: Add documentation standards, governance files, integration testing, performance baselines, complexity analysis, accessibility auditing, and (optionally) ML-specific practices for data-heavy Python repos.
migrationGuide.notes: Tackle recommended items in order of business value; backend-only repos can skip web-focused checks like accessibility. For AI/ML-heavy Python teams, consider extending containerization with data versioning (DVC) and unit tests with data quality checks (e.g., Great Expectations) as part of this step.

core.label: Git and Docker Ignore Files
core.description: Maintain proper .gitignore and .dockerignore files to prevent committing secrets, build artifacts, or unnecessary files.

stack.notes: Use the official github/gitignore Node template as a base and add .env*, node_modules, dist/, coverage/, *.log, npm-debug.log*, etc. .dockerignore must exclude node_modules, .git, and local build output.
stack.verification: .gitignore must exist; .dockerignore is recommended when containerizing or using Docker workflows.

core.label: Linting
core.description: Run static code linting to enforce consistency and catch common issues early.

stack.notes: Treat new lint errors as CI failures; keep existing issues as warnings until addressed.
stack.verification: Presence of eslint.config.js (or any .eslintrc* file) indicates linting is enforced for the repository.

core.label: Unit Test Runner
core.description: Provide a deterministic unit test framework with a single command to run all tests.

stack.notes: Keep unit tests fast and deterministic; move slow or flaky tests into integration or E2E suites.
stack.verification: Test framework configuration is present; test script is defined in package.json.

core.label: Containerization (Docker / Docker Compose)
core.description: Provide a Dockerfile and, if applicable, a docker-compose file for local dev and CI parity.

stack.notes: Use multi-stage builds and pin Node.js and base image versions in the Dockerfile to match CI (e.g., node:22-alpine).
stack.verification: Dockerfile must be present; docker-compose.yml is optional and indicates orchestration usage.

core.label: Semantic Versioning
core.description: Use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH versioning with clear rules and automated changelog generation based on commit history.

stack.notes: Drive versions and changelog from Conventional Commits; publish changelog as part of the release artifacts. Protect release branches and ensure release tooling only runs there.
stack.verification: Check that the version field follows SemVer, and trigger the configured release workflow (for example, a dry run of semantic-release or standard-version) to confirm it generates the expected next version and changelog entries.

core.label: Commit Linting
core.description: Enforce structured commit messages such as Conventional Commits.

stack.notes: Enforce commit message format via commit-msg hooks (e.g., Husky) before CI.
stack.verification: Create a test commit using the documented convention and ensure the commit message passes the configured commit linting or wizard (for example, commitlint or commitizen).

core.label: Unit Test Reporter / Coverage
core.description: Generate readable unit test and coverage reports and enforce a minimum coverage threshold (around 80%) for new or changed code.

stack.notes: Collect coverage in lcov or similar format; use diff coverage so legacy gaps are visible but non-blocking.
stack.verification: Run the unit tests with coverage enabled and confirm that a coverage report is produced and that the configured threshold (around 80%) is enforced for new changes.

core.label: CI Quality Gates
core.description: Single CI pipeline that runs linting, formatting, type checking, tests, coverage, build, and containerization.

stack.notes: Expose a single npm script (e.g., `npm run ci`) that mirrors the CI pipeline so contributors can reproduce failures locally.
stack.verification: Open the CI configuration and verify there is a job or stage that runs linting, type checking, tests, build, and any required container checks before merging to main.

core.label: Code Formatter
core.description: Automatic code formatting to maintain a consistent style across all contributors.

stack.notes: Run Prettier in check mode in CI; auto-fix locally via pre-commit hooks or editor integration.
stack.verification: Run the formatter in check mode (for example, `npm run format:check`) and confirm it reports clean formatting on committed code and auto-fixes as expected locally.

core.label: Pre-Commit Hooks
core.description: Use git hooks to run linting, formatting, tests, and commit linting before changes are committed.

stack.notes: Run ESLint and Prettier on staged files and enforce commit message format via commit-msg hooks.
stack.verification: Inspect the pre-commit and commit-msg hooks (for example, files under .husky or other hook tooling) and confirm they run linting/formatting and commit linting on staged changes.

core.label: Type Checking
core.description: Use static type checking to catch errors before runtime and enforce strictness on new code.

stack.notes: Enable strict mode ('strict': true) and treat type-check failures as CI failures for new code; gradually expand strictness into legacy modules.
stack.verification: Presence of tsconfig.json indicates type-checking is configured for the repository.

core.label: Dependency Management & Vulnerability Scanning
core.description: Lock dependencies and scan regularly for known vulnerabilities; fail CI on newly introduced high-severity issues.

stack.notes: Require a lockfile for reproducible installs and pin Node.js/tooling versions; block merges on new high-severity vulnerabilities.
stack.verification: Dependency lockfile is present; security scanning is configured in CI or project tooling.

core.label: Documentation Standards
core.description: Maintain a comprehensive README and, where applicable, auto-generated API docs to support onboarding and maintainability.

stack.notes: README should describe setup, scripts, and architecture; generate API docs from TypeScript types and JSDoc where helpful.
stack.verification: README.md is present in the repository root; docs/ directory or documentation tooling configuration exists if applicable.

core.label: Repository Governance
core.description: Include standard governance files (LICENSE, CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md, CONTRIBUTING.md), branch protection rules, and review standards to define legal, ethical, and workflow expectations.

stack.notes: Use an SPDX license identifier in package.json and describe review expectations, tests, and docs requirements in CONTRIBUTING.md.
stack.verification: LICENSE file is present in the repository root; CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md and CONTRIBUTING.md are present for contribution guidance.

recommended.label: Integration Testing
recommended.description: Test how components interact with each other and external systems, running after unit tests with more relaxed coverage thresholds.

stack.notes: Use Supertest for HTTP APIs and Playwright or similar tools for end-to-end flows; keep integration suites slower but reliable.
stack.verification: Confirm there is a separate integration or end-to-end test command or configuration and run it to verify that cross-component flows behave as expected.

recommended.label: Performance Baselines
recommended.description: Establish performance baselines and monitor for regressions using lightweight benchmarks or audits in CI.

stack.notes: Run Lighthouse CI for web apps and basic Node benchmarks on critical endpoints; schedule runs or limit to key branches to keep CI fast.
stack.verification: Identify and run the configured performance or Lighthouse-style checks and verify that key metrics are captured and compared to documented baselines.

recommended.label: Complexity Analysis
recommended.description: Measure cyclomatic complexity or similar metrics to keep code maintainable, starting as a warning-only check.

stack.notes: Warn on overly complex functions and methods; fail CI only when new or modified code exceeds thresholds.
stack.verification: Run the configured complexity tooling or rules (for example, ESLint complexity rules or Sonar analysis) and review any hot spots, ensuring new code does not exceed agreed thresholds.

recommended.label: Accessibility Auditing
recommended.description: Run accessibility checks on web-facing components to detect critical issues and improve inclusive UX.

stack.notes: Run accessibility checks against key pages or components in CI; fail on critical violations while treating minor issues as warnings initially.
stack.verification: For web-facing apps, run the configured accessibility tooling (for example, axe, pa11y, or Lighthouse accessibility audits) against key pages and confirm that critical issues are resolved.

optionalEnhancements.label: Observability (Logging & Error Handling)
optionalEnhancements.description: Standardize error handling and structured logging to make debugging and production monitoring easier.

stack.notes: Adopt structured JSON logging with correlation IDs and send logs to a centralized sink in production.
stack.verification: Confirm that a structured logging library (such as Winston or Pino) is configured to emit JSON or key-value logs and that error handling routes important failures through this logger.
